Role_Team.Subject: Geography
Role_Team.positionality: As a Product Owner pursuing a Master's in Geography, my research interest leans towards the intersection of economic patterns and spatial dynamics. My background in project management informs my structured approach to studying economic factors, while my academic pursuit deepens my understanding of geographical influences. I hold the epistemological assumption that knowledge is constructed through spatial and economic interactions. This assumption potentially biases my interpretation towards emphasizing systemic patterns over individual actions. My positionality shapes my research by encouraging a multidisciplinary approach that bridges geography and economics, ensuring that my findings are both contextually grounded and practically applicable. This reflection facilitates a balanced framework, aligning my scholarly work with my professional and personal insights.

init_codebook.definition: Emphasizes the role of the process in achieving software quality.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions process improvements as a component of quality.
exclusion_criteria: Discussions focusing solely on product features.
typical_examples: The agile process itself is subject to continuous improvements.
atypical_examples: Quality is subjective.
init_codebook.notes: Focus on process-oriented aspects of quality.

init_codebook.definition: Highlights the significance of internal code and design quality for software.
inclusion_criteria: Discusses clean code, design sustainability, or code reviews.
exclusion_criteria: Statements about product features without mentioning internal aspects.
typical_examples: Internal quality has to do with the way that the system has been built and designed.
atypical_examples: Software quality is the end result.
init_codebook.notes: Importance of internal aspects in quality.

init_codebook.definition: Defines quality in terms of meeting business needs and being defect-free.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions product being defect-free and meeting customer needs.
exclusion_criteria: Focuses on internal code quality.
typical_examples: Product quality can be simply defined as being defects free and add a business value.
atypical_examples: Quality takes place at the process level.
init_codebook.notes: Focus on defining quality by external standards.

init_codebook.definition: Describes the ongoing process of reflection and improvement in software development.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions retrospectives, learning from mistakes, or improvement efforts.
exclusion_criteria: Discussions of isolated process improvements and not iterative.
typical_examples: The more you work in the process and continuously improve it the better we become at achieving quality.
atypical_examples: We use checklists and documented guidelines.
init_codebook.notes: Emphasis on iterative development and learning.

init_codebook.definition: Highlights the role of team collaboration in enhancing quality.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions sharing knowledge, learning from peers, or teamwork.
exclusion_criteria: Talks that focus on individual efforts only.
typical_examples: Collaboration helps better quality by facilitating intensive exchange.
atypical_examples: Everyone needs to ensure quality.
init_codebook.notes: Focus on teamwork in quality assurance.

init_codebook.definition: Involves using customer interactions and feedback in refining software quality.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions user feedback or requirements refinement.
exclusion_criteria: Feedback loops that are purely internal to development.
typical_examples: The feedback helps us to improve the quality and reduce bugs.
atypical_examples: Quality is subjective.
init_codebook.notes: Integration of customer insights into development.

init_codebook.definition: Focuses on the sense of responsibility toward quality within the team.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions personal responsibility, accountability, or ownership.
exclusion_criteria: General teamwork without specific individual accountability.
typical_examples: People feel accountable to meet the team's expectations on quality.
atypical_examples: Stakeholders holding accountability.
init_codebook.notes: Encourages quality through personal responsibility.

init_codebook.definition: Emphasizes testing processes as fundamental to achieving quality.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions unit tests, peer reviews, or validation techniques.
exclusion_criteria: Discussions on quality without test-related context.
typical_examples: We have a strategy for what to automate and what to manual test.
atypical_examples: Quality happens at every project phase.
init_codebook.notes: Includes all aspects of test-driven quality assurance.

Role_Team.Subject: Statistics
Role_Team.positionality: As a software developer with a bachelor's degree in statistics, my research interest lies at the intersection of economics. My background equips me with technical skills to analyze data-driven economic models. However, I am conscious that my cultural and personal biases may influence my interpretation of statistical findings, potentially skewing economic conclusions. My goal is to employ rigorous methodology to mitigate these biases. Acknowledging the limitations of my positionality allows me to approach research with a critical mindset, striving for objectivity while recognizing how my role identity and academic background shape my understanding and analysis of economic phenomena.

init_codebook.definition: Quality is achieved through continually improving the development process.
inclusion_criteria: References to improvements in the software development process that enhance quality.
exclusion_criteria: Direct references to product or code quality without mentioning process.
typical_examples: The agile process itself is subject to continuous improvements.
atypical_examples: The system has been built with robust practices.
init_codebook.notes: Focuses on process as a factor of quality.

init_codebook.definition: Quality is defined by the product's conformity to business needs and lack of defects.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions of product meeting business needs and being free of defects.
exclusion_criteria: References to internal code quality or process quality.
typical_examples: For the software or the end product, I believe the key attributes is conformity to business needs and free of defects.
atypical_examples: Software quality is the end result.
init_codebook.notes: Focuses on final product attributes.

init_codebook.definition: Quality is a subjective concept, difficult to define universally.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions of quality being subjective or having varying definitions.
exclusion_criteria: Objective criteria like business needs conformity and defect-free.
typical_examples: It is a challenging question, because quality is a subjective concept.
atypical_examples: Quality is defined by standards.
init_codebook.notes: Highlights the subjectivity in quality definition.

init_codebook.definition: Internal quality includes maintainability, understandability, and reusability of code.
inclusion_criteria: References to internal aspects like code maintainability and reusability.
exclusion_criteria: External product quality such as user satisfaction.
typical_examples: The final product may confirm to business needs...but we have to add desires to maintain, understand, and reuse the code.
atypical_examples: The software is bug-free.
init_codebook.notes: Focuses on internal code and design aspects.

init_codebook.definition: Emphasizes on continuous process improvements through retrospectives.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions of retrospectives and continuous improvements.
exclusion_criteria: Static process definitions not involving improvements.
typical_examples: We use retrospectives to continuously reflect on the way we work.
atypical_examples: Process definitions without improvement considerations.
init_codebook.notes: Emphasizes use of retrospectives as improvement tools.

init_codebook.definition: A shift towards improving internal code quality in Agile development.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions the shift towards code quality.
exclusion_criteria: Focuses solely on defect levels without internal process.
typical_examples: I saw in agile a shift toward code quality and a design that responds to change.
atypical_examples: Focus on only eliminating product defects.
init_codebook.notes: Notes a shift in focus in Agile environments.

init_codebook.definition: Software quality seen as encompassing structural (code/design) and external (user-related defects).
inclusion_criteria: Distinct mention of structural and external components.
exclusion_criteria: Focus on either one component.
typical_examples: Software quality has a structural perspective...and an external component.
atypical_examples: Discusses only structure or only defects.
init_codebook.notes: Combined view of quality.

init_codebook.definition: Quality assurance involves a robust process subjected to reviews.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions of having a robust or strong process.
exclusion_criteria: Quality checks without process emphasis.
typical_examples: To achieve that we need a robust software development process.
atypical_examples: Nonspecific quality mentions without process emphasis.
init_codebook.notes: Emphasizes robustness of process.

init_codebook.definition: Emphasis on maintainable code adhering to established guidelines.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions guidelines for maintainable, readable code.
exclusion_criteria: Quality mentions devoid of code standards.
typical_examples: We aim for clean code that conforms to well established guidelines.
atypical_examples: Discusses prescriptive coding without guideline mention.
init_codebook.notes: Emphasis on coding standards for quality.

init_codebook.definition: Software quality as both a process and product outcome in Agile.
inclusion_criteria: Defines quality in terms of process and outcome.
exclusion_criteria: Focuses solely on one aspect (process or product).
typical_examples: Software quality is both outcome and process.
atypical_examples: Focus on a single aspect of quality.
init_codebook.notes: Blends process and product focus in Agile.

init_codebook.definition: Product quality defined by functionality meeting business needs.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions products meeting business or user needs.
exclusion_criteria: Quality talks devoid of conformity to needs.
typical_examples: Software quality can be defined as the ability of the software to function as per user requirements.
atypical_examples: Discusses architecture without needs conformity.
init_codebook.notes: Clarifies product quality by meeting needs.

init_codebook.definition: A committed team and strong process deliver quality software.
inclusion_criteria: Involves team commitment to process enhancing quality.
exclusion_criteria: Quality initiatives excluding process or team commitment.
typical_examples: Chaos doesn’t deliver software, but a committed team and a strong process does.
atypical_examples: Quality focus that excludes process or team engagement.
init_codebook.notes: Blend of team commitment and process in delivering quality.

init_codebook.definition: Agile focuses on clean, sustainable code adaptable to future changes.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions Agile's focus on clean, sustainable code.
exclusion_criteria: Agile talks without code sustainability mentions.
typical_examples: In agile, we respond to change over following a plan. Clean code is subjective, but it should be simple, readable, and maintainable.
atypical_examples: Agile discussions excluding code sustainability.
init_codebook.notes: Focuses on Agile's code philosophy.

init_codebook.definition: Quality emphasized as product being free of bugs.
inclusion_criteria: Talks emphasizing bug-free software as quality.
exclusion_criteria: Quality that involves more than being bug-free.
typical_examples: Free of bugs. The business doesn’t like buggy software.
atypical_examples: Quality discussions without bugs mentioned.
init_codebook.notes: Emphasizes defect-free quality.

init_codebook.definition: Definitions of quality encompassing product, internal, and process aspects.
inclusion_criteria: Talks mentioning product, internal, and process as quality aspects.
exclusion_criteria: Excludes formation of any of the three aspects.
typical_examples: Quality has three aspects: product quality, internal quality, and the process by which we deliver the software.
atypical_examples: Focus on two out of three components only.
init_codebook.notes: Three-part approach to quality.

init_codebook.definition: Agile equates quality improvement with continuous process enhancements.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions Agile's focus on continuous process improvement.
exclusion_criteria: Quality references without improvement context.
typical_examples: The process is a continuous improvement job. From my experience, organizations do not get the process right from the first go.
atypical_examples: Quality focus without process improvements.
init_codebook.notes: Continuous process improvement as a quality focus.

init_codebook.definition: Team collaboration enhances quality through shared learning.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions collaboration leading to learning and quality.
exclusion_criteria: Quality notions absent collaboration.
typical_examples: They share their knowledge better. They share their understanding of the requirements and why a bug is a bug and how to resolve it.
atypical_examples: Quality talks without collaboration.

init_codebook.definition: Quality is supported by transparency and accountability in the team.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions transparency in the team fostering quality.
exclusion_criteria: Quality interpretations that don’t involve transparency.
typical_examples: Transparency leads to openness, transparency leads to more questions, more questions lead to more answers, and more answers lead to less bugs and better quality.
atypical_examples: Quality perceptions lacking transparency mention.
init_codebook.notes: Transparent environments were seen as fostering quality improvements.

init_codebook.definition: Developer and QA collaboration impacts quality assurance processes.
inclusion_criteria: References developer and QA roles in ensuring code quality.
exclusion_criteria: Quality processes stated without developer or QA role.
typical_examples: Collaboration helps better quality by facilitating intensive exchange of information and feedback.
atypical_examples: Quality discussions lacking role-specific collaboration.
init_codebook.notes: Highlights team member collaboration in code quality enhancements.
Discusses diverse aspects of quality: collaboration, roles, transparency, and quality phases.

Role_Team.Subject: Anthropology
Role_Team.positionality: As a software developer pursuing a master's degree with a focus on anthropology, my research interests lie at the intersection of cultural systems and economic structures. I aim to explore how technology impacts economic practices and societal norms. My background in software development often inclines me towards viewing these phenomena through a technical lens, which may lead to underestimating more nuanced cultural factors. My ethical and societal assumptions push me to prioritize equitable technology use. This positionality influences my research by shaping the questions I ask and the methodologies I employ, striving for a balance between technological innovation and cultural sensitivity in understanding economic behaviors.

init_codebook.definition: This code captures references to software quality being defined or evaluated at the process or software development level.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions of quality assurance practices during the software development process.
Discussions about process improvements related to quality.
exclusion_criteria: Statements focused solely on the end product's quality.
Discussions about quality in unrelated contexts.
typical_examples: But for the purpose of a definition, I would say quality takes place in the process level and the software level.
atypical_examples: During the software development process, we implement and exercise practices that assure quality.
init_codebook.notes: Focus is on quality originating from the processes used during software development.

init_codebook.definition: This code captures references to quality being defined at the product level, including its ability to meet business needs and lack of defects.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions of end product quality, defect-free software, or meeting business needs.
References to product-level quality attributes.
exclusion_criteria: Discussions about the quality of the development process or internal code structure alone.
typical_examples: Product quality can be simply defined as being defects free and add a business value or at least meets the user needs.
atypical_examples: To achieve that we need a robust software development process that is subjected to continuous review and improvements.
init_codebook.notes: Emphasis is on the overall quality of the software product from a user or business perspective.

init_codebook.definition: This code refers to internal software quality measures such as clean code, simplicity, and flexibility in design.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions of code cleanliness, maintainability, and design flexibility.
Discussions on internal software quality improvements.
exclusion_criteria: External quality attributes or strictly process-focused quality measures.
typical_examples: Internal quality has to do with the way that the software has been constructed or built.
atypical_examples: Yes! An important and difficult question.
init_codebook.notes: Focus is on the software's architecture and its inherent quality attributes, as opposed to final product quality.

init_codebook.definition: This code indicates discussions about continuous improvement in software processes and quality relevant to Agile principles.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions of retrospectives, ongoing process improvement, and learning from mistakes in Agile.
Discussions about iterative enhancements of the software development process.
exclusion_criteria: One-time improvements or fixes that are not part of a planned continuous process.
typical_examples: The agile process itself is subject to continuous improvements.
atypical_examples: Quality can be defined in many ways.
init_codebook.notes: Emphasizes the Agile principle of iteratively improving both processes and quality.

init_codebook.definition: This code captures references to the practice of reviewing code by peers to ensure software quality.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions of peer reviews, code review processes, or feedback on coding practices.
exclusion_criteria: General discussions on software testing without mention of code reviews.
typical_examples: We assure it by code review and having guidelines and standards.
atypical_examples: Yes, good question.
init_codebook.notes: Focuses on peer review as a mechanism for maintaining or enhancing quality.

init_codebook.definition: This code captures the impact of Scrum practices on team collaboration and software quality.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions of Scrum ceremonies, teamwork, and improved communication or trust.
exclusion_criteria: Discussions solely focused on technical details without mention of team practices or collaboration.
typical_examples: If implemented correctly, yes, sure. Absolutely, because what Scrum did, because in a sense, agile doesn't speak to quality directly.
atypical_examples: Very broad topic, but I'll keep it simple.
init_codebook.notes: Emphasizes the role of Scrum in fostering a cooperative and efficient environment for quality software development.

agreements.reason: Both roles emphasize continuous process improvements, retrospectives, and learning from mistakes as a key aspect of software quality, aligning with Agile principles.
Both roles recognize internal quality as being related to maintainability, code cleanliness, and design, highlighting its importance in software development.
Both roles identify process improvements as integral to achieving software quality, albeit with slight variations in naming and inclusion criteria.
Both roles define product quality as aligning with business needs and being defect-free, indicating a shared understanding of quality from the product outcome perspective.

disagreements.reason: This code captures an understanding that quality is subjective, appearing only in the software developers' codebook, suggesting disagreement on whether quality has an objective or varying definition.

While collaboration is noted by both roles, the Product Owners focus on team collaboration as direct to quality enhancement, whereas software developers discuss it as part of a broader process, indicating slight variations in emphasis.

This code is specific to the Product Owners, focusing on testing processes for quality assurance, while the equivalent code in developers was 'Code_Review', showing divergence in the specific practices emphasized.

Captures the effect of Scrum practices on software quality, noted only by developers, suggesting it's not a consideration highlighted by Product Owners, indicating a divergence in perspectives on methodologies impacting quality.
Product Owners emphasize personal responsibility for quality, a focus not jointly reflected in software developers' codebooks, indicating differing views on individual roles in achieving quality.

data_source.literature_based: In qualitative research, user engagement is often used to measure interactions within a system or community. Established frameworks such as Grounded Theory and Thematic Analysis suggest defining metrics specific to user behavior for more detailed analysis.
data_source.content_based: The intent of the 'User_Engagement_Metrics' code is to capture quantitative metrics like page views, duration, and interaction counts that signify user engagement.
data_source.logic_based: The concept of measuring engagement through metrics is useful for practical applications and provides distinct value not covered by more qualitative observations.

discussion_results.reasoning: The data indicate that 'User_Engagement_Metrics' provides a distinct perspective by focusing on quantifiable elements of user interaction. No current agreed codes explicitly cover this quantitative aspect, making it important to retain this code for a comprehensive analysis of user engagement.
discussion_results.justification: The code adds unique value by specifically addressing the measurement of engagement through metrics, which is not overlapping with existing codes focused on qualitative engagements.

data_source.literature_based: Emotional response is a well-established category in qualitative research, particularly in domains exploring human-computer interaction and user experience design.
data_source.content_based: The code captures users' affective reactions, such as satisfaction or frustration experienced during interaction with a system.
data_source.logic_based: It provides a clear and distinct boundary by capturing emotional aspects not covered by behavioral or factual engagement metrics.

discussion_results.reasoning: The code 'Emotional_Response' offers distinct insight into the affective state of users, which is a critical component in understanding overall user experience alongside metrics. It complements other codes instead of overlapping.
discussion_results.justification: Distinct focus on emotional reactions provides additional dimensions that are not otherwise covered in the existing code list, ensuring more holistic insights are drawn.

data_source.literature_based: Frameworks that handle barriers and challenges in user experiences often explore platform limitations as a separate category. This might include usability constraints, feature restrictions, or technical barriers.
data_source.content_based: This code is intended to categorize issues and constraints users face which can affect overall engagement and satisfaction.
data_source.logic_based: Clear boundaries and explicit utility in understanding challenges users face specifically due to platform constraints, not covered by feature-specific feedback.

discussion_results.reasoning: Existing codes do not address limitations that are inherent to the platform itself, which are essential for identifying areas that limit user engagement and satisfaction.
discussion_results.justification: The distinct nature of platform limitations provides insights into areas requiring improvement for better user engagement and is not redundant with agreed codes.

codebook.definition: Emphasizes the role of the process in achieving software quality.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions process improvements as a component of quality.
exclusion_criteria: Discussions focusing solely on product features.
typical_examples: The agile process itself is subject to continuous improvements.
atypical_examples: Quality is subjective.
codebook.notes: Judge Rationale: Conceptual alignment with 'Process_Level_Quality', but retaining as they articulate distinct process-focused quality understanding across related roles.

codebook.definition: Highlights the significance of internal code and design quality for software.
inclusion_criteria: Discusses clean code, design sustainability, or code reviews.
exclusion_criteria: Statements about product features without mentioning internal aspects.
typical_examples: Internal quality has to do with the way that the system has been built and designed.
atypical_examples: Software quality is the end result.
codebook.notes: Judge Rationale: Agreed upon as distinct by all agents, necessary to encapsulate internal facets of software quality.

codebook.definition: Defines quality in terms of meeting business needs and being defect-free.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions product being defect-free and meeting customer needs.
exclusion_criteria: Focuses on internal code quality.
typical_examples: Product quality can be simply defined as being defects free and add a business value.
atypical_examples: Quality takes place at the process level.
codebook.notes: Judge Rationale: Emphasizes product-level quality, agreed and distinct role in codebook as aligned across roles.

codebook.definition: Describes the ongoing process of reflection and improvement in software development.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions retrospectives, learning from mistakes, or improvement efforts.
exclusion_criteria: Discussions of isolated process improvements and not iterative.
typical_examples: The more you work in the process and continuously improve it the better we become at achieving quality.
atypical_examples: We use checklists and documented guidelines.
codebook.notes: Judge Rationale: Retained for its consistent emphasis on iterative improvement, aligned in understanding between Product Owners and Developers.

codebook.definition: Highlights the role of team collaboration in enhancing quality.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions sharing knowledge, learning from peers, or teamwork.
exclusion_criteria: Talks that focus on individual efforts only.
typical_examples: Collaboration helps better quality by facilitating intensive exchange.
atypical_examples: Everyone needs to ensure quality.
codebook.notes: Judge Rationale: Retained as a distinct concept highlighting teamwork, with different emphasis across roles which is methodologically supported.

codebook.definition: Emphasizes testing processes as fundamental to achieving quality.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions unit tests, peer reviews, or validation techniques.
exclusion_criteria: Discussions on quality without test-related context.
typical_examples: We have a strategy for what to automate and what to manual test.
atypical_examples: Quality happens at every project phase.
codebook.notes: Judge Rationale: Retained due to its focus on methodological assurance of quality, distinct from broader discussion on code review.

codebook.definition: Focuses on the sense of responsibility toward quality within the team.
inclusion_criteria: Mentions personal responsibility, accountability, or ownership.
exclusion_criteria: General teamwork without specific individual accountability.
typical_examples: People feel accountable to meet the team's expectations on quality.
atypical_examples: Stakeholders holding accountability.
codebook.notes: Judge Rationale: Retained as an important culture-specific aspect of quality assurance, emphasizing individual role-linked responsibility.
